As a teenager, Lloyd developed a keen interest in music and eventually formed the band Public Image Ltd (PiL) with his former bandmate, John Lydon, in 1978. PiL played a crucial role in shaping the post-punk movement, with their politically charged and experimental approach to music. Over the years, they released numerous acclaimed albums such as "Metal Box" (1979), "1984" (1979), "The Flowers of Romance" (1981), and "This Is What You Want... This Is What You Get" (1984).

Throughout the 1980s, Lloyd continued to contribute to the music industry, both as a member of PiL and as a solo artist. His solo works, including "Happy?", "9", and "99%," showcased his unique blend of electronic, rock, and avant-garde elements, earning him critical acclaim and solidifying his place in music history.

Apart from his music career, Lloyd has also ventured into filmmaking and acting. He played the character Doc Emmett Brown in the "Back to the Future" trilogy, which catapulted him into the mainstream and led to his becoming an internationally recognizable figure.

In the later years, Lloyd has been active in the production side of the industry. As a co-founder of Invisible Records, he has supported and promoted various emerging artists. Additionally, he has lent his voice and acting skills to a host of other notable projects such as the film "I'm Not There" (2007) and the TV series "Mr. Robot."

Christopher Lloyd's impact on the music and entertainment industry has been profound, leaving a lasting legacy that will continue to inspire future generations of artists and creators.
